image.altText: Woman stands behind bush with green leaves on a sunny day with face blurred

items.synopsis: Darwin resident Sue lives on the fringe of a PFAS contamination zone and is one of the 30,000 Australians involved in a class action against the Defence Department.

title.children: 'Did they know?': Sue is one of thousands of Australians taking the Defence Department to court

image.altText: Jasmina, woman in pink sihrt smiling, holding a baby wearing a blue shirt.

items.synopsis: Michelle and Jono Harley always dreamed of having a family — their devastating fertility journey took a twist when relatives stepped in with an extraordinary back-up plan.

title.children: 'They need an oven and I have to cook it': Why Jasmina, 52, gave birth to her grandson

image.altText: An older white man in heavily armoured combat gear and a helmet stands on a rooftop, with a soldier looking out behind him.

items.synopsis: Today, as Russia's President Vladimir Putin flails around dispatching one failed military chief after another, Yevgeny Prigozhin – for the moment at least – is probably the safest Russian in the world, writes John Lyons in Kyiv.

title.children: Putin needs this man more than anyone else — until the moment he ceases to be of use

image.altText: A composite of images of a young and old Mick Doleman and a shipwreck under the ocean.

items.synopsis: The wreck of the Blythe Star is located almost 50 years after it sank off the Tasmanian coast, its crew believed dead — until, astonishingly, they appeared out of the bush far from where the ship sank.

title.children: The crew of the Blythe Star were thought lost at sea. So why did they stumble out of a forest?

image.altText: Composite image of a Korean man smiling and an Australian woman smiling.

items.synopsis: As South Korea edges closer to being solely powered by renewables come 2050, the manufacturing industries of Australia's third-largest trading partner believe hydrogen gas is the answer to help reach its target.

title.children: Korea's demand for Australian hydrogen has never been higher. Is it the start of a new mining boom?

image.altText: A line stretches back as far as the eye can see outside Centrelink.

items.synopsis: You can define a "recession" in different ways. Are we experiencing one now? asks Gareth Hutchens.

title.children: What is a recession? Are we experiencing one now?

image.altText: A rescue boat in the water with at least four people on board.

items.synopsis: A man has died and two other people have been treated for hypothermia after spending four hours in the water off the West Australian coast.

title.children: One dead, two rescued after boat accident off Geraldton coast

image.altText: Three mugshots of three separate men. The first has tattoos on his face. The second has a beard. The third has darker skin.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Manhunt for three escaped prisoners, and Paddington and the Queen win a BAFTA. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The BAFTA TV awards have wrapped up in London, with the likes of The Traitors, Derry Girls, Bad Sisters and even Paddington Bear taking home awards for the best in British TV. Kate Winslet won the BAFTA for leading actress for her role in I Am Ruth, while Anne-Marie Duff won supporting actress for her portrayal of Grace Williams in drama series Bad Sisters. Ben Whishaw won leading actor for his portrayal of Adam Kay in autobiographical drama This is Going to Hurt, while Adeel Akhtar won the BAFTA for supporting actor for his role in the crime drama Sherwood. Derry Girls won in scripted comedy, with Sister Michael actress Siobhán McSweeney winning for female performance in a comedy programme. Entertainment performance was won by Claudia Winkleman for The Traitors, which won for reality and constructed factual. But the memorable moment award, the only award voted for by the public, was won by Paddington and Queen Elizabeth II's Party at the Palace sketch for the late monarch's jubilee … … and Paddington is pretty excited about it. You can see the full list of winners and nominees at the Baftas website .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Queen Elizabeth II and Paddington are among the BAFTA TV award winners

children.content: The BAFTA TV awards have wrapped up in London, with the likes of The Traitors, Derry Girls, Bad Sisters and even Paddington Bear taking home awards for the best in British TV.
Kate Winslet won the BAFTA for leading actress for her role in
I Am Ruth
, while Anne-Marie Duff won supporting actress for her portrayal of Grace Williams in drama series
Bad Sisters

props.alt: Kate Winslet, winner of the leading actress BAFTA for I Am Ruth, holds up the award next to her head.

children.content: Kate Winslet, winner of the leading actress BAFTA for I Am Ruth.
(Reuters: Maja Smiejkowska)
Ben Whishaw won leading actor for his portrayal of Adam Kay in autobiographical drama
This is Going to Hurt
, while Adeel Akhtar won the BAFTA for supporting actor for his role in the crime drama
Sherwood
Derry Girls
won in scripted comedy, with Sister Michael actress Siobhán McSweeney winning for female performance in a comedy programme.
Entertainment performance was won by Claudia Winkleman for
The Traitors
, which won for reality and constructed factual.
But the memorable moment award, the only award voted for by the public, was won by Paddington and Queen Elizabeth II's
Party at the Palace
sketch for the late monarch's jubilee …
… and Paddington is pretty excited about it.
You can see the full list of winners and nominees at the
Baftas website

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A manhunt is underway after three men escaped from a Queensland prison on Sunday. The men escaped from Palen Creek Correctional Centre, which is about 100 kilometres southwest of Brisbane. Authorities are now on the hunt for Daniel Ian Badcock, 32; Osiah Pilton, 20; and Antonio David Mene, 28. Badcock was serving a one year sentence for possession and weapons charges. He is described as having a medium build, with a diamond tattoo on the left side of his face and the word 'Opmerta' tattooed over his right eye. He has other tattoos including the word 'Outlaw' on his left shin and knuckle dusters tattooed onto his right hand Pilton, who was serving one year and nine months for a break and enter offence, is described as having black hair and eyes with the word 'Mum' tattooed on his left arm above the wrist, and a diamond tattoo on his left leg Mene who was serving three years for vehicular offences, is described by police as being Torres Strait Islander, about 170 cm tall with the outline of his last name tattooed on the inside of his right arm Police have urged anyone who has seen the men not to approach them but to call triple zero.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Manhunt underway after three men escape a Queensland prison

props.alt: Three mug shots of men, one with a beard and one with tattoos on his face

children.content: (AAP: Queensland Police)
A manhunt is underway after three men escaped from a Queensland prison on Sunday.
The men escaped from Palen Creek Correctional Centre, which is about 100 kilometres southwest of Brisbane.
Authorities are now on the hunt for
Daniel Ian Badcock, 32; Osiah Pilton, 20; and Antonio David Mene, 28

Badcock was serving a one year sentence for possession and weapons charges. He is described as having a medium build, with a diamond tattoo on the left side of his face and the word 'Opmerta' tattooed over his right eye. He has other tattoos including the word 'Outlaw' on his left shin and knuckle dusters tattooed onto his right hand

Pilton, who was serving one year and nine months for a break and enter offence, is described as having black hair and eyes with the word 'Mum' tattooed on his left arm above the wrist, and a diamond tattoo on his left leg

Mene who was serving three years for vehicular offences, is described by police as being Torres Strait Islander, about 170 cm tall with the outline of his last name tattooed on the inside of his right arm
Police have urged anyone who has seen the men not to approach them but to call triple zero.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After passing over Bangladesh's Saint Martin's Island, Cyclone Mocha has hit Myanmar, tearing roofs off buildings and killing at least three people. The cyclone made landfall on Sunday afternoon in Myanmar's Rakhine state near Sittwe township, with winds of up to 209 kilometers per hour, Myanmar's Meteorological Department says —making the storm a dangerous category five cyclone. The extent of the damage in Sittwe isn't clear just yet. Earlier yesterday, high winds crumpled mobile phone towers, cutting off communications in much of the area. In videos collected by local media before communications were cut off, deep water races through streets while wind lashes trees and pulls boards off roofs. Myanmar's military information office says the storm damaged houses, electrical transformers, phone towers, boats and lampposts in Sittwe, Kyaukpyu, and Gwa townships. It says the storm also tore roofs off of sport buildings on the Coco Islands.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Cyclone Mocha has killed at least three people

props.alt: People walk through a flooded street in Myanmar

children.content: (AP)
After passing over Bangladesh's Saint Martin's Island, Cyclone Mocha has hit Myanmar, tearing roofs off buildings and
killing at least three people
The cyclone made landfall on Sunday afternoon in Myanmar's Rakhine state near Sittwe township, with
winds of up to 209 kilometers per hour
, Myanmar's Meteorological Department says —making the storm a dangerous category five cyclone.
The extent of the damage in Sittwe isn't clear just yet.
Earlier yesterday,
high winds crumpled mobile phone towers
, cutting off communications in much of the area.

props.alt: A map showing a cyclone over parts of India and Myanmar

children.content: (India Meteorological Department via AP)
In videos collected by local media before communications were cut off, deep water races through streets while wind lashes trees and pulls boards off roofs.

Myanmar's military information office says the storm damaged houses, electrical transformers, phone towers, boats and lampposts in Sittwe, Kyaukpyu, and Gwa townships. It says the storm also tore roofs off of sport buildings on the Coco Islands.

image.altText: Zoe Bettison standing behind five microphones talking

items.synopsis: For governments, social media influencers have become a communication frontline particularly as they try to connect with young people. But evaluating the success of such strategies is hard to do, writes Rory McClaren.

title.children: Influencers, TikTok and taxpayer dollars: The world of tourism marketing in the social media age

image.altText: Sam kerr is mid-backflip with Chelsea teammates around her after a goal in the Women's FA Cup final.

items.synopsis: Sam Kerr scores her fifth goal from the past three FA Cup finals as Chelsea beats Manchester United 1-0 in front of more than 77,000 fans at Wembley.

title.children: Record crowd packs out Wembley to watch Sam Kerr win FA Cup for Chelsea

image.altText: Recep Tayyip Erdogan looks down in front of a black background while standing next to the Turkish flag

items.synopsis: Türkiye appears headed for a run-off presidential election, with the parties of both Recep Tayyip Erdoğan and opposition rival Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu both claiming the lead.

title.children: Türkiye run-off election likely as both President Erdoğan​​​​​​​ and opposition leader claim lead

image.altText: A woman in blue scrubs in a hospital bed.

items.synopsis: Bunbury cancer survivor Fiona May thought she was peri-menopausal after doctors said she had nothing to worry about — but that changed when she collapsed while on holiday.

title.children: Fiona thought her fatigue and weight gain were early signs of menopause, then she collapsed

image.altText: Lara Alexander wears a black coat and blue and pink scarf and stands on a suburban Launceston street

items.synopsis: Newly-independent MP Lara Alexander says a "huge weight" has been lifted from her shoulders, while the Tasmanian Greens' push to axe Hobart's new stadium look set for failure without Labor's support.

title.children: 'A huge weight lifted': MP relieved after becoming an independent, but headaches ahead for now-minority government

image.altText: Light shines through a window onto a man wearing a blue jumper and glasses.

items.synopsis: Residents in a riverside retirement village that flooded last October, extensively damaging dozens of homes, say they were staggered to learn the village had a limit of $5 million for flood insurance.

title.children: 'We built on a swamp': Flood insurance at disaster-struck retirement village had $5 million limit

image.altText: A smiling man wearing a light blue shirt with his arms down and hands together

items.synopsis: The search continues along beaches on South Australia's Eyre Peninsula for local teacher Simon Baccanello, who is believed to have been killed in a shark attack while surfing on Saturday morning.

title.children: Search continues for South Australian surfer missing after shark attack

image.altText: A woman leans against a wooden post in front of vegetation wrapped around a leaning fence.

items.synopsis: Farmer Tess Herbert says the family farm lost millions of dollars worth of crops when the town of Eugowra in the NSW central west was hit by an 'inland tsunami'.

title.children: Six months on from 'inland tsunami', community cries out for support

image.altText: A composite image of Anthony Albanese and Linda Burney in front of the Uluru Statement

items.synopsis: What is it, how will it work and who's for and against it? We break down everything to do with the Indigenous Voice to Parliament referendum.

title.children: We keep hearing about a Voice to Parliament. What is it and how would it work?

image.altText: A black board with a message remembering the life of someone

items.synopsis: The life of a 23-year-old international student has been remembered at a concert in Darwin, with community leaders renewing calls for greater government action to prevent crime.

title.children: 'We do not forget': Concert held remembering life of student who died after alleged violent home invasion

image.altText: Person leaning over a table wearing a hooded gown, with a box of tissues and a mug on the table.

items.synopsis: This respiratory virus is so common that most children will have had at least one infection before they turn two. Most cases are mild, but it can cause severe illness for young children, the elderly and the immunocompromised.

title.children: Australia has been counting RSV cases for less than two years. Here are the basics about the common cold virus

image.altText: A composite image of Jack Riewoldt, Michael Voss and Nick Blakey

items.synopsis: An emotional rollercoaster for Carlton, Richmond party like it's 2017 and Sydney reach their tipping point in a potentially defining round nine. We digest the week that was.

title.children: AFL Round-Up: Blues' broken hearts, Tigers' greatest hits and Swans' breaking point

image.altText: Light streaks at night are seen behind a white cross beside a road.

items.synopsis: Independent monitoring of the national road toll finds deaths on Australia's roads have risen in almost every state and territory, prompting concerns the National Road Safety Strategy is failing.

title.children: 'Difficult to understand': Road toll rises in almost every state and territory

image.altText: Jim gestures as he speaks at a podium.

items.synopsis: Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers has refused to rule out the Coalition's proposal to increase the JobSeeker income free threshold, but Social Services Minister Amanda Rishworth has dismissed it as a "thought bubble with no substantive analysis behind it".

title.children: Peter Dutton proposal has 'no substantive analysis behind it' but Jim Chalmers refuses to rule it out

image.altText: Bernard Arnault stands between his two oldest children

items.synopsis: When the world's richest person sits down for monthly lunches in Paris with his five children, he's searching for his successor. Welcome to the house of Arnault.

title.children: He's called the 'wolf in cashmere'. Now the world's richest man needs to pick a child to succeed him

image.altText: An Aboriginal woman sitting at a conference table inside a room, seen from the back.

items.synopsis: Legislation passed by the NT parliament this week will pave the way for Aboriginal elders and leaders to have a say on what sentences some First Nations offenders should receive.

title.children: Aboriginal elders will soon help decide the criminal sentences of some Aboriginal offenders. So, how will it work?

image.altText: Liberal party MP Moira Deeming exits from a joint party meeting, wearing a blue dress.

items.synopsis: Moira Deeming says she feels she was "relentlessly hunted" before being expelled from the parliamentary party room, but will never quit the Liberal Party.

title.children: 'I will not do their dirty work for them': Ousted MP vows to never leave the Liberal Party

image.altText: French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne standing next to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in front of a French plane.

items.synopsis: President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says Ukraine is preparing a counteroffensive designed to liberate areas occupied by Russia, not to attack Russian territory, while two Russian commanders are killed in fighting near Bakhmut.

title.children: Zelensky makes surprise visit to Paris for talks on Ukraine's urgent needs

image.altText: Ron DeSantis greets audience members during a fundraising picnic for U.S. Rep. Randy Feenstra

items.synopsis: Decrying a "culture of losing," Florida Governor Ron DeSantis tries to weaken Donald Trump's grip on the Republican Party in Iowa after the former president is forced to cancel a rally in the battleground state due to a hurricane warning.

title.children: 'A culture of losing': Ron DeSantis blames Donald Trump for GOP woes during Iowa rally

image.altText: Women hold children and walk on flooded streets while drenched by rain.

items.synopsis: A powerful cyclone has killed at least three people and caused substantial damage in Myanmar, but so far it has spared the densely populated refugee camps in neighbouring Bangladesh.

title.children: Deadly Cyclone Mocha hits Myanmar and Bangladesh coasts

image.altText: A lone runner is dwarfed in the foreground by a rugged red landscape with a large mountain in the distance

items.synopsis: After studying YouTube videos, one of two international runners in the gruelling West Macs Monster outback challenge wants to make the most of his trip to Australia and attempt something no-one's tried before.

title.children: 'Cool dad' to attempt epic back-to-back Larapinta Trail ultramarathons

image.altText: Loreen performing on stage with hands out and a camera in front of her.

items.synopsis: The Eurovision song contest has wrapped up for another year with the UK hosting the competition for last year's winners Ukraine. Spoilers ahead.

title.children: Eurovision song contest grand final crowns winning act

image.altText: Kate Middleton sits in a blue dress whilst playing piano.

items.synopsis: Princess of Wales Kate Middleton makes a surprise appearance in the opening segment of the Eurovision grand final, playing the piano.

title.children: 'A Eurovison surprise': Princess of Wales makes video apperance at Eurovision

image.altText: a platypus is released into the waters of a national park

items.synopsis: The iconic Australian animal is believed to have disappeared from Sydney's Royal National Park after a major chemical spill on the Princes Highway in the 1970s.

title.children: 'Let girls settle in': Platypuses return to national park's waterways after being extinct for decades

image.altText: sepia toned photograph of a young gary tonkin holding up the four-metre whale jaw on a wooden jetty.

items.synopsis: For 30 years, scrimshander Gary Tonkin, 74, scratched away on the jaw bone and teeth of a sperm whale, creating intricate engravings telling the story of an American whaling ship, The Kathleen, that went from hunter to hunted.

title.children: Delicate carvings on a giant whale jawbone tell a grim seafaring tale in this disappearing art form

image.altText: A woman and a man near Ayers Rock in Northern territory.

items.synopsis: A Queensland woman last seen on South Australia's western Eyre Peninsula a week ago is found by a member of the public who saw her "wandering out of the scrub". Her family say she's now recovering in hospital.

title.children: 'I just broke down': Family's relief as Queensland woman found a week after going missing in SA town

items.synopsis: A deep divide has arisen over the High Court and role it could play over a Voice to Parliament. For some, it's raising echoes of past Indigenous rights battles, writes Elizabeth Byrne.

title.children: The Voice offers echoes from debate around past High Court decisions
